fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-376].
  {panel}

We've been using the service desk for a while, and have been trying out different configurations.   

For some reason, the service desk has created multiple custom fields of type "Customer Request Type".  All of them have the same description, and say "Please do not remove"

Service desk should not create duplicate fields of this type, or if it does, then it needs to provide you with a way to maintain them, and to distinguish between when/why they were created.  

See attached screenshot - how am I supposed to manage this?  Is is ok to delete them, even though it says not t?

These fields are confusing users in the search screen, and make it hard to write custom scripts, etc, as it's unclear which field is being referred to
fields.summary: Improved maintenance of "Customer Request Type" custom field

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-367].
  {panel}

We have a project where we enforce privacy via Security Levels. 

Repro Settings:
* security level required in Field Config
* security level scheme has a default security level set
* security level is not changeable by the end-user

As an admin, if I now go to configure a Service Desk portal, it will show me an error: "Oops something is broken" and claim that my forms are disabled until I set a value.

This is not true, the forms are still enabled, even if I do not set a value for security level in Service Desk Portal forms.

Expected Result: I think security level is a special field that needs more testing. It probably shouldn't show that error since the forms still display to end-users, nor force users to pre-set a value since it defaults to one anyway.

h4. Workaround

One of the following:

# Disable issue level security for the service desk project
# Change the field configuration to make the issue security an optional field
fields.summary: Security Level field produces inconsistent errors in Service Desk portal config
Ability to show/hide Queues with specific users/groups

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-365].
{panel}
h3. Actual

In every JIRA you have Customers who also use JIRA for there projects. For this group of users it is hard to track there requests outside the customer portal if you give them only the permission to use the customer portal. They have already a dashboard to track their issues, but they lost the focus on there open Service Desk requests.

It's much harder to keep an eye on your request if the user has access to multiple Service Desks.
h3. Exprected behaviour

Create a new JIRA Gadget where users get an overview about their unresolved Service Desk Requests. 
 Due to the SD 1.2 restrictions it is not possible to use the filter gadget.
{panel:title=Update 24th November 2020}
We appreciate the merit of this issue, but don't intend to work it in the foreseeable future. We'll review it again within a year to see if our decision has changed.  

Thanks, 
JSM Team.
{panel}

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-358].
  {panel}

h3. Summary of bug

When enabling Service Desk for an existing project, if there are already existing issues that are closed, those issues will not have the SLA counter, and as such will not be counted into the SLA reports

h3. Steps to reproduce

# Create a project and a few issues
# Close some of the issues (but not all)
# Enable Service Desk for that project
# Check the closed issues, there will not be any SLA there.

An example :

The project PNS has 5 issues :

!SDS1.png|thumbnail!

When searching for {noformat}project = PNS and "Time to resolution" = breached(){noformat}
the results contains 1 issue :

!SDS2.png|thumbnail!

When searching for {noformat}project = PNS and "Time to resolution" != breached(){noformat}
the results contains 3 issues :

!SDS4.png|thumbnail!

There is one more issue missing, and that issue was actually closed before Service Desk was enabled for this project. As such, the results from the two queries does not add up to the total amount of issues contained in the project.

h3. Additional Info

* Although the closed issues will not have any SLA, the issues that are not closed yet will have SLA
* If the closed issues are re-opened, then SLA will be enabled for it. However, the SLA will be reset
* When Service Desk is activated for a project, the SLA information is actually already stored in the database, even for the closed issues. However, for some reason, it is not showing in the UI of the issue.
fields.summary: SLA is not enabled for closed issues

The My Requests page in the Customer Portal should allow for some way to sort current requests as a customer using Service Desk.
 * Currently is sorted from oldest to newest.
 * A specific example would be Sort by Status.


**

*UPDATE by [~6cf75f652d57]*

*We have released the following:* 
 # Jira Admins can remove any existing column in the request list page (customer portal) 
 # Jira Admins can add the following columns
 ## created date
 ## Updated date
 ## Due date
 ## Assignee
 ## Priority
 # Your *customers can now sort* on most of these columns. 

*How to do this:* 

If you are a Jira Admin, you can go to 'https://<your instance>/servicedesk/customer/user/requests?page=1', and click on the 'Customize' sidebar, you should be able to customize the columns that your customers see in this page. 

[Support Documentation|https://support.atlassian.com/jira-service-management-cloud/docs/untitled-entry-2021-03-05-at-09-29-32/]

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-349].
  {panel}

{panel:title=Updated 12 October 2021}

Hi everyone,

We are currently updating this and will be surfacing the request type in the global issue create. When a request type is selected, we will show the request type configuration, including the field names, field help and field configuration (mandatory fields etc.).

We will be releasing this January 2022.

Thanks for your patience, we are aware that this is a major pain point and are working hard to improve the experience.

Thanks,

Jehan Gonsalkorale | Product Manager | Jira Service Desk Cloud
{panel}

h3. Problem Definition
It is currently not possible to change the issue type on Service Desks. All fields are editable except *Issue Type*, which is greyed out.

!request.png|thumbnail!

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow to modify *Issue Type* and possibly provide option to apply to existing requests or only for new requests
 
h3. Workaround 
Remove and/or add a new *Request Type* with the desired *Issue Type*

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-335].
  {panel}

h3. Summary of Issue

When using Service Desk 1.2, the 'Create KB' button in the issues are no longer working. When the user clicks on it, nothing will appear (a tiny dropdown menu should appear)

h3. Steps to Reproduce 

# Install Service Desk 1.1.6 first, and connect it to a Confluence space
# Upgrade Service Desk to 1.2 or above
# Try to create a KB from an issue

In the browser development tools, under the 'Console' menu, the following will appear :

{code}
GET http://10.60.2.150/jira61/rest/servicedesk/1/servicedesk/MINE/kb/create-draft?issueId=11601&_=1392386955632 400 (Bad Request) batch.js:8243
ajax[79755633] error : {
successful  : false,
status      : 400,
statusText  : error,
hasData     : true,
readyState  : 4,
requestId   : 79755633,
aborted     : undefined,
} 
{code}

!create KB.png|thumbnail!

h3. Workaround

As a temporary workaround, downgrade your Service Desk to 1.1.6
fields.summary: Create KB button no longer works in Service Desk 1.2

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-334].
  {panel}

h5. Actual
When you choose *Migrate permission scheme* then it only changes the scheme and nothing more.

h5. Description
If you have an existing project with enabled comment security by project roles these will not change.
|| Roles before Migration || Roles after Migration ||
| * Administrator
* Helpdesk 
* Helpdesk & Second Level
* Second Level
* Users | * Administrator
* Helpdesk 
* Helpdesk & Second Level
* Second Level
* Service Desk Team
* Service Desk Customer
* Users |

The team will now see 2 additional roles. 
When you remove the users from the not needed roles (e.g. Helpdesk & Second Level becomes Service Desk Team) they will not see their old comments.
To fix this you have to [manipulate the database|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/wwFlEg].

h5. Expected
Create an interactive migration process where you choose your existing roles and which it should be. Then all existing issue comments will changed automatically.

Due to the greater impact of this change (see additional), restrict the migration only to users with jira-administrators permission.

h5. Additional
Extend the migration notes that an adminstrator has more to change than the permission scheme if:
* you have a notification scheme with roles
* you have groovy or jelly scripts which contains the old role name or role id
* you have an issue security level which contains these roles
* you have to role based conditions / validators / post functions in your workflow
fields.summary: Improve the migrate permission scheme process

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-325].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently JIRA Service Desk does not allow SLAs to be displayed on the customer portal. Customer should be able to see certain SLAs as defined by agents/administrators, for example to know the initial response time in order to manage expectations accordingly.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add an option to the configuration of each SLA so administrators can choose whether the SLA should or not be displayed in the customer portal.

{noformat}

However it's not obvious in the application (without reviewing the logs) what the problem is.

Please improve JIRA Service Desk so that it notifies users about this.

h3. Workaround

Configure the Application Link so that it uses OAuth as described in [Application Links User Guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/APPLINKS/Application+Links+User+Guide].
fields.summary: As an administrator of the Service Desk I would like it to notify me if the Application Link is not properly configured
customer problem 1

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-320].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
On the queue page, only icons are showing on *Issue Type* column. Users need to hover-over to the icon to full Issue Type name

h3. Suggested Solution
Ability to configure the text in the column name and also how the Issue Type is displayed (e.g. short text or icon).

h3. Why this is important
This is not convenient to categorise the issues as some issues types are using the same issue type icon. 

h3. Workaround 
# Use different icons for each issue type to differentiate them
# Replace with *Request Type*

{panel:title=Original Request}
h3. Current Behaviour:
The column for the Issue Type in the Service Desk Queue displays only a T on the column name, and the icon for the type itself:
!Screen Shot 2014-02-12 at 7.26.44 PM.png!
Mousing over the Issue Type icon displays the Issue Type name.

As a JSD user, I would like to configure the text in the column name and also how the Issue Type is displayed (e.g. short text or icon).
{panel}
fields.summary: As a Service Desk user, I would like to be able to see the issue type description in the Queues
JSD reports in Dashboard
Service Desk menu in JIRA should use project avatars

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-313].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

When a project is deleted and added again, the project key conflicts with Service Desk and causes certain actions to fail. This is caused by Service Desk not deleting its data when a project connected to it is deleted.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Add a project.
# Add a Service Desk to that project.
# Delete the project.

h3. Expected Results

JIRA works without any problems.

h3. Actual Results

The following exception is thrown when trying to access Service Desk:

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-306].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

A Service Desk project could have request types where the underlying issues have been removed from the project (issue type scheme), but not deleted.
If a user does NOT have access to any projects where the issue type is actually used, then the request type admin page does not load.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Upgrade an instance with problematic data to Service Desk 1.2.

h3. Expected Results

The upgrade goes ahead without any problems.

h3. Actual Results

The request type configuration screen will fail to load and display a spinning cog.

h3. Workaround

# Edit the Issue Type Scheme for the project used by the Service Desk and add all available Issue Types.
# Go back to the requests screen and remove the unwanted request types.
# Edit the Issue Type Scheme and remove the Issue Types that were just added to workaround the problem.

{panel:title=Atlassian update as of 17th May 2017}
{panel}
Hi all,

We've recently made it possible to add multiple languages for your portal and have resolved this issue for JIRA Service Desk Cloud.

Check out the new "Language Support" section to manage translations for both the customer portal and email notifications. Read more about it [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/servicedeskcloud/blog/2017/05/translate-your-customer-portal]. 

Thanks again for your help in tackling this problem.

Cheers,

JIRA Service Desk Team

 
{panel:title=Atlassian update as of 16th November 2016}
{panel}
Hi all,

Thanks for all your comments. There's certainly a lot of interest behind this feature!

We would love to hear more from you on how your team shall add and maintain multiple languages on the portal. Understanding this will help us make the right thing that fits your needs perfectly.

If you would like to help out, please take 2 minutes to answer these questions - [https://jsd-beta.typeform.com/to/VS5QKT].

Cheers,
JIRA Service Desk Team

I suppose you could still use the regular JIRA interface to achieve this. But there is problem with the Activity Stream when the user is restricted to the Customer Portal.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-299].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
I agree with the design decisions to make SLA a project level concept, rather then using Schemes after using the system a bit, but think there is still the need for some polish for teams that may have a single JIRA project, for both customer facing intake and backend development. (i.e. Stories and Epics along with Bugs and Support).

Some tickets are just not driven by SLA. We don't track "first response" on developer driven stories. It does not make any sense to see SLA clocks and fields on our User Stories, Epics, or technical tasks. Those timelines are all driven by a separate queuing, priority and intake process (scrum, etc), and make the SLA Reporting of the service desk inaccurate.


h3. Proposed Changes 

h3. The Bullets


* SLAs are the global concept, not the measure (/) <-- I like this, makes perfect sense
* The use of a Scheme, or selection of issue types might encourage bad patterns (duplicate SLA concepts) (/)
* Goal's JQL are the only means to decide if an SLA is tracked or excluded for particular issue types (!)
** I dislike the default "All Remaining Issues" Goal, and think that should be eliminated. OR
** I think this is where a logical split between SLAs and Goals should be applied.


# SLAs should have categories/buckets/groupings
# Categories assign issue type
# Unassigned types ignored (A info box can call out untracked types as a warning in case of oversight)
# Each category has the same "Goals" functionality seen today.


 *Teams using a single project for both agile development and service desk should be supported*

h4. Sample Structure
{noformat}SLA - Time to Respond
 | - Category
 |    | - issues types  (Engagements, Coaching)
 |    ` - Goals (24 hours)
 | - Category
 |    | - issues types  (Incident)
 |    ` - Goals (2 hours blocker, 4 hours crtical, 8 for the rest)
 | - Category 2
 |    | - issues types (Support Request)
      ` Goals (8 hours Critical, 16 hours all else)
{noformat}

h4. Narrative

Each SLA (time to response) will have a series of groups that break up the nature of service desk work.  In my example this breaks up the work by the nature.  
* Engagements are large efforts, and require considerable up-front analysis. First response should always include a checklist of missing items.
* Incidents are critical issues a customer is facing, and may be blocking work.  This takes priority over engagements, and require much faster response, even if just "We know!, we're working on it!"
* Support fall somewhere in the middle.
There is also an implicit concept here.  User Stories and Epics by not being explicitly included, are excluded. These tickets are not tracked at all, as it makes no sense to track "first response" on developer driven stories.

So when creating or editing an SLA I should see a section of expandable headings (impl. details I dont care about) for each category of work.

For each category defined (or I add) I should pick a mutually exclusive list of issue types not already chosen by another category.  Any issueTypes not explicity applied to a category will be ignored.  (the system could create 1 new default category for each SLA containing all issue types for the project, and there is no loss of today's current status)


I should be able to define within those categories of work, the levels of service (Goal). This is where JQL makes sense to evaluate the priority, reporter, market, or whatever else.

----

The only work-around I see meanwhile is to leave the default SLA Goal empty, or set to "0" one existing ones, and then define new goals (actual goals), including issue type, priority, etc, as well as a new catch-all goal that still includes issue type, but nothing else.
!https://confluence.atlassian.com/download/attachments/408453925/Example1.png|width=400! but as I note this is a big PITA for a desk with multiple buckets of work and goals within those.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-294].
  {panel}

I am finding it takes about 2 hrs to create a new service desk. We will eventually need to create about 50+ for the major customers of our SAAS product. The management time for this is outweighing the benefits of using.

We require : 'Create Service Desk for "Customer B", user "CustB User", project "CustB project", using Template "Customer A Service Desk" '.

i.e. Service desk desperately needs templates for:
issue types on the customer portal
sla definitions
calendar
single project permissions (i.e. copy from existing permission scheme, create new and add user group)
etc.

If we want to adjust the SLAs for all service desks, we should be able to change a reference SLA scheme, not edit each desk.

Alternatively:
Allow a single service desk to be setup with everything parameterised  from the service desk name down to permissions etc. Requirement is for user from customer A to only see the single customer A project issues, SLAs etc.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-285].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
In JIRA ServiceDesk, you are able to add queues in order to organise work. This is good for categorising tasks based on various use-cases, such as Geographical Distribution of Employees, or to highlight issues that need the most amount of attention. 

Creating many queues causes a long list to form, which is may be difficult to navigate under some circumstances.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
In a JIRA Service Desk:
# Make many queues as per: [Make queues for your service desk teams|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/SERVICEDESK/Make+queues+for+your+service+desk+teams] 
# Observe that as the list gets longer, it is harder to navigate.

h3. Expected Results
A method to collapse, or arrange Service Desk queues in a logical fashion. 

h3. Actual Results
No method to arrange queues into sub-categories exists.

h3. Workaround
Some users have discovered by:
# Clicking the *Queues* Tab
# Create a *New Queue*
# Using Unicode characters such as: ↳ {{U+2183}} in the name of the queue, meets their requirements.

h3. Original Submitted Request:

Like anything else, as soon as you have more than a handful of queues, having some method to group queues become important.

This is what we have right now in our SD implementation, but what we really want is to be able to group queues ( and probably reports too ). See attached.

Our base scenario is that we are setting up a single Service Queue so we can have a single Customer Portal entry point, but we have multiple teams ( Systems Support, Software Support, Data, ... ) as service agents, and need to setup queues for them.

We also have multiple locations, and again want to offer a single entry point for our users, but share the backend so support teams can cover for remote locations ( which may or may not have local teams ). This could also be resolved if the customer portal was separated from the agent portal so they could be mixed and matched based on usage patterns ( one to one, many to one, one to many, ... )

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-273].
  {panel}

*Why:*
When browsing through old tickets for solutions/advice, there are often a handful of 'key' bounces that contain the bulk of the solution.

*What:* 
Allow comments to be star-able, so that when you wrap up a ticket, you can easily point out the solution to anyone who will view it in the future. Also allow for people reading through past tickets to star comments.

Starred comments will be un-collapsed when opening a ticket, allowing for future viewers to quickly find the answer.

As a service desk employee i want to see that a customer has other unresolved requests

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-270].
  {panel}

As a result of ------JSD-62------, customers will only be able to view and track their own requests using the Customer Portal.

Using the feature proposed in ------JSD-269------, it will be possible for customers to manually add request participants. However, it may be common for customers of a particular logical group (eg. organisation) to need to be granted default access view requests made by others from the same organisation.

Users from the same organisation should be able view, search and comment on requests. Users from different organisations should not be able to view each others' requests.

 
{panel:title=Update as of 3 Jan 2017}
Hello Server customers,

Great news - Customer organization is now available on server! To find out more about this feature, check out our documentation [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/SERVICEDESKSERVER033/Setting+up+service+desk+users].

On behalf of the JSD team I want to thank all of you for your patience. Your comments, feedback and interviews have all formed the feature update we release today.

— JIRA Service Desk Team
{panel}

  
{panel:title=Update as of 28 Sep 2016}
Hi all,

Great news! Customer organisation is now available on cloud! To find out more about this feature, check out our blog post and documentations [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/servicedeskcloud/blog/2016/09/group-customers-in-organizations].

This feature will also be available for Server in a future major server release.

On top of this we have also built public APIs so you can easily extend our feature to support your various usecases! Check out our API docs [here|https://docs.atlassian.com/jira-servicedesk/REST/cloud/#servicedeskapi/organization].

On behalf of the JSD team I want to thank all of you for contributing to this ticket. Your comments, feedback and interviews have all formed the feature we release today.

— JIRA Service Desk Team
{panel}
 
{panel:title=Update as of 15 Sep 2016}
Hi all,

We are at the tail end of the development process for this feature. We are currently performing final testing as this feature touches on many sensitive parts of our products relating to permissions and security model.

We also want to thank all of you who have joined us for the usability test, your feedback was very valuable and we have made a number of changes to the feature based on the feedback.

As mentioned earlier, this feature will be available to both Cloud and Server and will be available on Cloud first before Server as there are far less permutations to test and QA on our Cloud infrastructure.

Thank you all again for your patience.

— JIRA Service Desk Team
{panel}
 
{panel:title=Update as of 21 Jul 2016}
Hi all,

We do have a very vibrant marketplace which our expert partners develop add-ons that extend our products. [Collection Issue View for Service Desk|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/net.seibertmedia.jira.plugins.collective-issue-view/server/overview] and [Teams for JIRA Service Desk|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/eu.prepend.jira.servicedesk-teams/server/overview] are both add-ons which aim to provide customer grouping capabilities for JSD Server. If you are on JSD Server you can evaluate these options and choose to purchase them if they meet your needs.

As mentioned before this feature is one of our highest priorities and the JIRA Service Desk team is actively developing this capability. We are building it as a core part of the product, so there will not be any additional cost for this capability - and we are building it for both Server and Cloud.

Unfortunately the development of this feature is taking considerable time as the security model for users in Cloud is very different to Server. It also fundamentally changes the way our product works so we want to ensure we get it right.

If you are interested to see how the feature is progressing feel free to [leave your details|https://jsd-beta.typeform.com/to/TUqws8] to join one of our upcoming usability test and provide us feedback on the feature itself.

Thank you all again for your patience.

— JIRA Service Desk Team
{panel}
 
{panel:title=Update as of 27 Jun 2016}
Hi all,

This is one of our highest priorities and we have the best team working on the feature.

This feature fundamentally changes the way our product work and we want to ensure we get it right. We have been actively reaching out to this community for usability testing on our latest development and design work on this feature. If you are keen to see where we are up to with the this feature, you can [leave your details here|https://jsd-beta.typeform.com/to/TUqws8] to join one of our upcoming usability test and provide us feedback on the feature itself.

Thank you all again for your patience.

— JIRA Service Desk Team

 
{panel}
{panel:title=Update as of 3 May 2016}
Hey all,

We understand many of you will need to make business decisions around when this feature is available, however we do not have a meaningful ETA we can share. As mentioned in my previous comment this is already in active development but there are quite a few number of moving parts to implementing this feature.

We will do our best to keep everyone updated with the latest development regarding this feature and to share our designs/progress once they become available. Right now we are in the process of bringing in groups into JIRA Service Desk (Ability to add groups to tickets, JQL search for groups etc) and also making enhancements to the group infrastructure (Allowing agents to be managing groups etc).

Again I want to stress this feature requires big changes to our underlying user management and permission infrastructure. Both of these aspects are fundamental to how you manage your users and the access control of the system, and we need to take the time to make sure we are doing it in the best possible way possible. Thank you again for all your continuous feedback and I will do my best to make progress updates as we go along. :)

-JIRA Service Desk team
{panel}

To reproduce: 
When logged onto JIRA as a customer, go to Service Desk > Queues > whatever queue shows your requests > then you'll see list of issues with columns. 
We don't want our users to see some of the columns that are internally want to see. This will, of course, depend on what we have configured as fields for our issues. For example, we have due date, assignee, and Story Points as columns we don't want our clients to see. 

I don't see this as a show stopper for us but may become more important as we roll out and add more fields to our issue types.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-257].
  {panel}

h3. Current behaviour

Currently when you log into JIRA in the Service Desk section you will have a "My Requests" option in the header. If you click there, you will only see the issues created by you in that specific Service Desk project. If your issue is moved from one project to another for example, you will no longer see the issue there. For many customers it is very important to have the issue raised via Service Desk and then move the issue to the appropriate project to develop/fix/implement it properly, but the customer is no longer able to see the issue and keep track of it.

h3. Expected behaviour

We want the "My Requests" filter to show all of of the issues raised by the customer, independently of the project.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-249].
  {panel}

The simplified interface for the Customer Portal is great, but we have some workflows which present challenges, for instance, uploading a PDF.

Our PDFs could be one of 5 types, and each type has some specific metadata. Our current options are to either have 5 request types for uploading a PDF, or to put all the metadata options on one "Upload PDF' request.

It would be great if it were possible to have multiple steps in Customer Portal so that a customer could:

1. Click 'Upload PDF' request
2. Get a common screen which applies to all PDF upload requests.
3. Enter information, including a 'Document Type' for the request.
4. If the document type was set to 'Analyst Report' then provide a way for the user to give the metadata required only for that type.

This could be accomplished with multiple screens in a wizard setting, or with conditional fields which only appear when something is checked, e.g. an analyst report metadata fieldset which only appears when type is set to 'analyst report'.

h3. Current behaviour

Mail notifications are referring to a single ticket.

h3. User case / expected results

1. John submits a ticket to the service desk team.
2. John submits the same ticket 4 more times.
3. Emails to John include all 5 tickets, each with the same subject heading and body. 4 are marked as duplicate, and John is not confused because he knows there are 5 tickets.
